8ec6a80135c3.name: Deborah Hart Yemm

paragraphs.text: We have our own work to do. Our fellow citizens are as smart as we are, and they are not mistaken when they see a media that condescends to them and their values of patriotism, religion, community, natural recreation, and hard work. They are neglected often enough to read the clear suggestion that they are best left as consumers than as a topic of conversation. Yet I believe I am not the only one who would rather read stories about salt miners in upstate New York and Iowa farmers too happy to retire than about the sale of another celebrity’s Los Angeles mansion. Polarization depends on us failing to recognize our shared values, and a media that continues on as it does will only set itself up for further vilification.
paragraphs.name: ea80
b6ba
paragraphs.text: I admit I was at first surprised by the idea of combating political correctness with the election of a president, rather than, as a sensible person might do, by sharing George Carlin videos. One might militate against liberal pieties by writing a book or pitching an edgy TV show — effective measures that don’t simultaneously empower a chief executive who could revoke health care from millions, spark a recession, degrade the lives of brown citizens and Muslims, trash the environment, bomb more countries, disrupt stabilizing alliances, imprison more minor drug offenders, and jeopardize access to reproductive care. It strikes me as a desperately incomplete political vision to throw these matters into chaos to just gain pushback against sensitive broadcasters and college students.

paragraphs.name: 01a1
paragraphs.text: But so is the rapturous appeal of Trump’s narrative, which casts the people, neglected economically but more significantly neglected in status, as major participants in the American project once again. The hollowness of the rhetoric is easy to ignore when it carries so much rapture, as Bauerlein demonstrated an interview with Slate, where he described Trump’s inauguration address as less like demagoguery and “closer to the populism of Walt Whitman and his paean to the working man.”

Of course, these small betrayals won’t deter Trump’s idolators. The delicious simplicity of the conflicts both Trump and his sympathizers concoct are too precious to jeopardize with small changes in evidence. Both books come accompanied by dramatic and hyperbolic subtitles—Trump’s Plan to Save America, His Battle for America—implicating their authors in the role of holy crusader. What is one slip-up (or dozens) from your ally when the enemies you face are ruining the country in some insidious though unspecified way?

How do we deal with a percentage of the population either advocating racism, white nationalism, misogyny and general…

So they turn to those who promise…

It all comes down, in the end, to the question: what do we still share?
